title: Mastering Advanced Scrum — A Scrum Master Training Course
headline: In this free online course, you will master the skills necessary to become an advanced Scrum Master.
description: Mastering Advanced Scrum is a course for Scrum masters, Agile coaches, iteration managers, and delivery managers. You will learn to respond confidently to your team when faced with resistance to change, a lack of engagement, low motivation, or the absence of key personnel. Gain leadership skills and impact organizational change, such as expanding Scrum and Agile beyond a single team. Become a highly skilled Agile professional now!
courseDescription:
This course is the second in a series on becoming an advanced Scrum Master. If you haven't already, I recommend starting with part one: Introduction to Advanced Scrum – A Scrum Master Training Course. Free online advanced Scrum master training courses like this one are scarce. This course is built on the best learning objectives of the Scrum Alliance® and Scrum.orgTM to provide you with current, market-relevant content.

We have intended this course for Scrum masters, Agile coaches, iteration managers, delivery managers, and any Agile practitioners interested in discovering and improving their Scrum practice. You will discover how to boost participation to encourage greater accountability, commitment, and buy-in from your team. You will also gain leadership skills and impact organizational change, such as expanding Scrum and Agile beyond a single team.

We have created this course with two groups in mind—firstly, for students who are certified Scrum masters and want to advance. Secondly, for students wishing to gain an advanced understanding of the Scrum framework but are not concerned with passing any exams. Enroll in this course now and improve your implementation skills, distinguish yourself in the global marketplace, and demonstrate advanced value to your employer or potential employer as a highly trained Agile professional.

Start Course Now

Once you have completed this course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

slides:
• Learning Outcomes

  • Having completed this module you will be able to:
    • Identify the indicators of divergent and convergent thinking.
    • Discuss the challenges associated with integrating multiple perspectives.
    • Explain the Groan zone and how to make the best of it.
    • Describe some facilitative listening techniques for effective meetings/events.
    • Identify viable alternatives to open discussion.
    • State some conditions under which a Scrum Master should not act as a facilitator for the team.
    • List some collaborative Scrum events.
    • Explain proven strategies for removing obstacles to clear communication.

  • Impact on Team Performance

  • The practice of facilitation is one of the most misunderstood notions in the Scrum Master's responsibilities. Regardless of experience level, the art of facilitation is a critical talent that even the most seasoned Scrum Masters must constantly polish and hone. More often than not, a Scrum Master's ability to help the team as an effective facilitator can have an impact on the team's overall success.
  • Facilitation is the art and craft of enabling individuals and groups to discuss issues and opportunities around a shared objective and develop agreed strategies for a common direction.

    A facilitator is a neutral individual who acts as a catalyst for groups to solve problems and produce solutions.

  • Key Facilitation Skills for Scrum Masters

  • Do you want to be a great facilitator? If so, you'll need to learn particular skills in order to become one. Unfortunately, numerous myths about facilitation can deter you from pursuing it as a career. Some can also cause you to focus on the wrong topics, reducing the efficacy of your facilitation.

    Seven key facilitation skills have been compiled in this topic to help you become a great facilitator.

  • Agile Team Working Agreements

  • Working agreements, also known as team norms, are guidelines produced by teams that outline how they must collaborate to achieve a pleasant, productive process.

    Working agreements define desirable behaviors that, while simple, are not often evident in team activities. "We all agree to engage completely" may constitute an agreement.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Agreements are a group's power tool. Working agreement elements should be made public for easy reference throughout the collaboration process.

    The goal of establishing team norms is tocreate a ONE team culture that can be referred to when things get tense within the team.

  • Divergent Vs. Convergent Thinking

  • Convergent thinking focuses on reaching one, well-defined solution to a problem, while divergent thinking involves more creativity and accepts multiple solutions to a problem.
  • In practice, here’s what these different types of thinking might look like:
    • Convergent thinking: If the copy machine breaks at work, a convergent thinker would call a technician right away to fix the copy machine.
    • Divergent thinking: If the copy machine breaks at work, a divergent thinker will try to determine the cause of the copy machine’s malfunction and assess various ways to fix the problem. One option may be to call a technician, while other options may include looking up a DIY video on YouTube or sending a company-wide email to see if any team members have experience with fixing copy machines. They would then determine which solution is most suitable.

  • Let's Agree to Disagree

  • We may disagree on how to resolve a conflict or solve a problem, which is a divergent condition. An agreement is a convergent situation in which we reach an agreement on a resolution or solution.
  • Any mediator will tell you that the space between the two is valuable. And yet, we frequently rush through it, pressing our way to an agreement as if speed is the most important factor.
  • In the spirit of efficiency, we sometimes rush through arguments. However, it is inefficient to spend more time later picking up those metaphorical apples. Have you ever thought an issue was resolved only to discover that what appeared to be an agreement wasn't? There are so many apples around.
  • We also rush through disagreements because they are uncomfortable.

  • Reach a Decision

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Decisions must be taken at various points throughout a project. How those decisions are made will differ depending on the circumstances.

    What should a team do when it's tasked with reaching a choice or providing a proposal but can't come to an agreement?
  •  Leaders devote considerable consideration to the facts and analysis required to initiate and continue these types of talks. However, they rarely consider how they want to complete things. Of course, they shouldn't know what choice will be made ahead of time. But they should be aware of how it will be created if no one can agree.
  • What is ultimately essential is to have the support of the entire team and a knowledge of what was chosen and how it was decided.

  • Need for Facilitated Events

  • Why do we even need facilitation or a (high-quality) facilitator? It seems that a high-quality facilitator is too expensive. Following orders may have been acceptable in the 19th century when only a select few persons in positions of leadership and influence were aware of the unchanging facts. But in the twenty-first century, our world is becoming more complex, a wider variety of individuals can now access knowledge, and those in positions of authority are no longer the smartest people in the room. In the 21st century, collective intelligence and creativity are too valuable to be wasted; thus, we need excellent facilitators.
  • There will be a price to pay for maximizing collective intelligence because there will be so many different viewpoints present. There will be individuals with various demands, each with their own background and experience. People will have varying opinions and ideas due to their various positions and roles within the organization. Even though every voice has to be heard, not all voices are made equal.

    A smart Scrum Master can draw the most intelligence possible from these differences and diverse viewpoints. Therefore, facilitation is necessary if we wish to harness the numerous voices' potential to create a potent collective intelligence.

  • Imposing Processes and Practices

  • Scrum allows a blank area for most practices to fill, which is why it is flexible to a wide range of circumstances, industries, and businesses. These practices and processes are usually finished by industry jurisprudence: that is, best practices that are considered best for the project are chosen by the team and Scrum Master.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Without the team's consent, the Scrum Master may select and impose best practices to the best of his/her knowledge. 

    In some circumstances, this may work (which is problematic because it establishes a terrible precedent), but in others, the team may not adapt well to that method of working or even revolt against this imposition if the techniques are not carefully chosen.
  • Scrum is not prescriptive, and neither should the Scrum Master be. Remember that the Scrum Master is not a tech lead or project manager but rather the person in charge of ensuring that Scrum is correctly applied and that the processes are shaped and adapted to the project in its current condition.

  • Lesson Summary

    • A good facilitator should be genuine, objective & neutral, create a mindset of continuous learning, harness the power of collective intelligence, foster collective ownership, and instill focus and engagement.
    • Focus on 7 key facilitation skills: master the facilitation mindset, improve time management, shortcut circular discussions, keep energy levels high, curb team politics and groupthink, give clear instructions, and be flexible.
    • Use facilitative listening techniques to engage participants, ensure everyone is participating, and handle emotions. Working agreements develop a sense of shared responsibility & empower the facilitator to lead the group. 
    • Strategies to engage a group in divergent thinking include forming break-out groups, trying bubble maps, encouraging journaling, and trying role-playing. Engage a group in convergent thinking using grouping, outlining, or filtering.
    • Keep the groan zone discomfort to a minimum by acknowledging the groan zone’s existence, chunking it down, taking breaks, and giving yourselves permission to screw up.
    • Use fist of five voting, decider protocol, or the majority rule to help a group reach their ﬁnal decision.
    • Be aware of obstacles to effective communication:language misunderstanding, information overload, noise & distraction, lack of comprehension, status differences, and negative emotions. One good strategy is to slow down and keep it simple.
    • Don't facilitate by imposing practices, solving all impediments, taking sides, oversimplifying the process, and being the sole point of contact between the team and others.

  • Learning Outcomes

  • Having completed this module you will be able to:
    • Describe three elements of a coaching stance.
    • Apply an appropriate coaching technique for two interventions.
    • Analyze an intervention to identify at least two improvements.
    • Explain Scrum and its benefits to a business stakeholder.

  • Competencies of a “Coach”

  • A Scrum Master must acquire specific expertise and skills that will add value to a single team and the entire Agile/Scrum practitioner community. 
  • To be considered “Advanced,” even the most skilled Scrum Masters must excel in various roles as the team, and the organization expands its capabilities. 

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • As indicated in the Scrum Guide, a Scrum Master is expected to serve the team as a “coach.” 

    Since there are many different definitions regarding the competencies of a “coach,” this criterion is often interpreted in a variety of ways depending on organizational and business context.

  • The GROW Model

  • The GROW model is a tried-and-true coaching method that can assist coaches in ensuring efficient results for their clients.

    GROW stands for:
    • Goal
    • Reality
    • Options (sometimes Obstacles)
    • The way forward (sometimes Will or Wrap-up)

  • It’s All About Rhythm and Cadence

  • One of the Agile Manifesto's ideas is that we deliver working products/services to users by releasing them early and frequently, using an iterative and incremental methodology. This means that we use rhythm and cadence to distribute little bits of the product to clients regularly. 
  • For the Scrum Team, the organization, customers, and users, rhythm, and cadence minimize complexity and promote predictability. As a Scrum Master, you must recognize that having a rhythm in the business is quite beneficial when building complicated products or services in complex contexts.

    So, while creating a Sprint rhythm, shorter Sprints (2 weeks) should be preferred over longer Sprints since they create more rhythm and cadence.

  • Tips for the Sprint Planning

    • New Tab
    • Start with the Sprint Goal
    • Create an actionable plan
    • Take the Definition of Done into account
    • Take only 'Ready Items'
    • Plan for uncertainty
    • Enter your text here..
      Enter your text here..
    • Begin by developing the Sprint Goal with the Scrum Team. Scrum's aim is to enhance value for customers and users, thus it's critical to keep this in mind when working. 

      The idea is to generate as much output as feasible while producing as little input as possible. Remember, more output does not equal more results.
      Begin by developing the Sprint Goal with the Scrum Team. Scrum's aim is to enhance value for customers and users. Thus, it's critical to keep this in mind when working. 

      The idea is to generate as much output as feasible while producing as little input as possible. Remember, more output does not equal more results.
    • Create a clear and actionable Sprint plan, with tasks that can be completed in one day or less. I've found it really beneficial (and inspiring for the Development Team) to be able to complete numerous tasks in a single day. So, if you set aside 2-4 hours per day for work, you may make progress every day.
      Create a clear and actionable Sprint plan with tasks that can be completed in one day or less. I've found it really beneficial (and inspiring for the Development Team) to be able to complete numerous tasks in a single day. So, if you set aside 2-4 hours per day for work, you may make progress every day.
    • Consider the Definition of Done while developing a plan. The Development Team must execute work to provide the Product Increment in accordance with the Definition of Done. So, to plan quality ahead of time, use the Definition of Done during Sprint Planning to ensure that quality is taken into account.
      Consider the Definition of Done while developing a plan. The Development Team must execute work to provide the Product Increment in accordance with the Definition of Done. So, to plan quality ahead of time, use the Definition of Done during Sprint Planning to ensure that quality is taken into account.
    • Only 'Ready Items' should be brought into the Sprint. Make sure that every Product Backlog Item (that is being pulled into the Sprint) is clear and understood by all Development Team members before creating an actionable strategy for the Sprint. This promotes improved collaboration, communication, and comprehension of the task.
      Only 'Ready Items' should be brought into the Sprint. Make sure that every Product Backlog Item (that is being pulled into the Sprint) is clear and understood by all Development Team members before creating an actionable strategy for the Sprint. This promotes improved collaboration, communication, and comprehension of the task.
    • Prepare for uncertainty so that you can respond to changes during the Sprint. Every Sprint, something unusual happens. Changes will always occur during the Sprint, whether it is a bug, an event, or a new high-priority request. So prepare for this to happen. 

      Work does not have to be assigned to all team members. They do not have to be completely booked! Instead, encourage them to maintain some flexibility during the Sprint.

  • Lesson Summary

    • The Agile coach stances are teacher, mentor, coach, and change agent.
    • As coaches, Scrum Masters foster 2-way communication by giving effective feedback, asking open-ended questions, and using nonverbal techniques.
    • Scrum Masters utilize motivational techniques, Group Coaching Techniques, and Life Coaching Techniques.
    • The GROW model (Goal, Reality, Options, Way forward) is a solid, time-tested coaching tool that can help Scrum Masters ensure efficient results for their teams.
    • Both end and performance goals need to be: SMART (Specific, Measurable, Actionable, Realistic, Time-bound), PURE (Positively stated, Understood, Relevant, Ethical), and CLEAR (Challenging, Legal, Environmentally sound, Appropriate, Recorded)
    • Scrum Masters monitor, sense, and feel what is going on in the team in order to train, mentor, coach, and support the team in becoming a little bit better every day.
    • Scrum Masters use coaching and teaching tips and tricks to make Scrum events even more effective so that the team can promote collaboration, optimize productivity, foster transparency, and adapt on their way to learning and improving throughout the project lifecycle.

  • Learning Outcomes

  • Having completed this module you will be able to:
    • Identify at least three elements to refine a team's identity.
    • Describe the aspects of appreciating unique skills and talents in a team.
    • Explain why everyone on a Development Team needn't know how to write code.
    • Identify at least 3 elements required for effective self-organization.
    • Explain assets that help teams reap the benefits of effective collaboration.

  • Not Just Putting People Together

  • A strong team is essential for agile success. The ideal team is cohesive, cross-functional, and self-organizing, yet most teams begin as a collection of individuals who must learn how to work together to achieve their common goals.
  • Members of new Scrum Teams, particularly those who are not accustomed to working in a cross-functional team, may struggle initially to generate "Done" Product Increments in every Sprint.

    You can't just gather a group of individuals and tell them, "You're a team," and expect them to achieve great things.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Forming a team entails investing in getting a group of people together to accomplish something they could not do alone. The team members work together to create a totally new live and breathing organism that develops an identity over time.

  • Members of new Scrum Teams, particularly those who are not accustomed to working in a cross-functional team, may struggle initially to generate "Done" Product Increments in every Sprint.

    You can't just gather a group of individuals and tell them, "You're a team," and expect them to achieve great things.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Forming a team entails investing in getting a group of people together to accomplish something they could not do alone. The team members work together to create a totally new live and breathing organism that develops an identity over time.

  • How Do Scrum Teams Collaborate?

  • A self-managing, cross-functional team must learn to collaborate. To accomplish this, team members must invest in developing "collaborative assets."Five assets assist teams in reaping the benefits of good collaboration.
  • These assets complement one another. 

    It is impossible to have the other four assets if you do not have trust. It is hard to have commitment, accountability and shared goals if there is no productive conflict. 

    For each asset, repeat the process.

  • Lesson Summary

    • A team’s identity is shaped by answering three questions: Why do we exist—what is our purpose? What is important to us—what values do we hold dear? What do we want to achieve together?
    • Successful teams are composed of members who are self-aware enough to understand their strengths, have sufficient emotional intelligence to adapt their reactions to those around them, and are intrinsically motivated to work with others to achieve things that they could not achieve on their own.
    • Not everyone on a Development Team has to know how to write code, and creating a valuable “Done” Increment requires much more than just writing code.
    • Effective self-organization requires three things: shared goals, clear accountabilities, and boundaries. If any of these weaken, the team may lose the ability to self-organize and become less effective.
    • Five assets help teams reap the benefits of effective collaboration, and these build upon one another.
    • If you don’t have trust, having the other four assets will be impossible. If you don’t have productive conflict, it will be impossible to have commitment, accountability, and shared goals.
